awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Data on the Edge: Leveraging Edge Datacenters for Low-latency, Fault-tolerant, mobile Geo-replicated Transactional Data Stores
awd_abstract_narration:
Data-intensive computing is the driver of the continuing growth and success of global Internet services and cloud applications. The system infrastructure for data-intensive computing is built and run on top of compute resources housed in large, centralized data centers. These data centers are typically placed away from populous regions for economic reasons. This leads to a fundamental limit on the speed of communication between users and data centers.  To overcome this limit, the project aims to extend data management systems to be edge-aware.  Edge-awareness is the capability of utilizing resources that are closer to users to reduce the latency they experience by one to two orders of magnitude.

The project will investigate two closely related research challenges to enable edge-aware data management systems. The first research challenge focuses on one of the most important building blocks of distributed systems, namely the problem of agreement between different nodes (also called the consensus problem.) The project proposes a design of a new consensus protocol that, unlike existing consensus protocols, is edge-aware and thus enables preserving consensus and fault-tolerance while achieving the low-latency performance enabled by edge-awareness. The second research challenge is building edge data management systems that react efficiently to user mobility. The project proposes augmenting consensus protocols with a mobility component that enables handling user mobility efficiently while preserving consensus and fault-tolerance.

Large sectors of business and industry, in addition to the modern style of living, increasingly rely on data-intensive Internet and cloud applications.  This project aims to advance the data and system infrastructure for these applications. The project will also provide the opportunity for undergraduate and graduate students to learn and work on fundamental data management systems research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Replicating data across datacenters (geo-replication) increases the level of fault-tolerance and availability of internet scale applications. Unfortunately, as the scale of geographical distribution increases maintaining the replicas consistent with each other becomes a hard problem especially since it takes a long time to achieve communication across different datacenters across the world. Combining geo-replication with the edge computing model by utilizing compute resources at the edge (i.e., computing resources near the users) enables bringing data closer to users and expanding the resource pool. Prior geo-replication techniques do not utilize edge resources efficiently. The goal of this proposal was to develop edge-aware geo-replication. In this project, we tackle the challenges of edge-aware geo-replication through a design of a new protocol that we call Local Paxos (El-Paxos). El-Paxos is a Paxos-based consensus protocol for emerging edge computing architectures. El-Paxos is designed with the salient properties of the edge computing model in mind. It utilizes nearby edge datacenters for computation, storage, and fault-tolerance, thereby avoiding the cost of expensive wide-area network communication. El-Paxos design intentionally separates diverse concerns in Paxos, namely, leader election, replication, and fault-tolerance. This separation also results in a better understanding of consensus protocols. The major outcome of El-Paxos is to reduce the latency of serving user requests and recovering from failures. The broader impact of edge-aware data management is that it enables the efficient and consistent date management of global-scale data that is essential for Internet Services that drive global connectivity and e-commerce, and global-scale Big Data analytics. This infrastructure is critical for the success of emerging edge and mobile applications, which impacts all aspects of our daily lives. From an education perspective, the research supported by this award directly impacted the upper division undergraduate courses on databases and distributed systems as well as graduate courses on big data, data science, cloud computing and datacenter technologies.
